title: CVE-2023-28319: UAF in SSH sha256 fingerprint check

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
The fingerprint_b64 pointer is as parameter for failure logging after it is freed.

## Steps To Reproduce:
1. git clone https://github.com/curl/curl
2. vim curl/lib/vssh/libssh2.c
3. search for the string 'free(fingerprint_b64)' and note that fingerprint_b64 is used as parameter immediately after it is freed.

## Supporting Material/References:
The following are the details of the code.

git commit a51f90ec0f74176776f5d14b99689f9241660eaa (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)

In curl/lib/vssh/libssh2.c
 653 static CURLcode ssh_check_fingerprint(struct Curl_easy *data)
 654 {
 ...
 667     char *fingerprint_b64 = NULL;
 ...
 729     if((pub_pos != b64_pos) ||
 730        strncmp(fingerprint_b64, pubkey_sha256, pub_pos)) {
 731       free(fingerprint_b64);
 732 
 733       failf(data,
 734             "Denied establishing ssh session: mismatch sha256 fingerprint. "
 735             "Remote %s is not equal to %s", fingerprint_b64, pubkey_sha256);

According to git blame, the following commits were involved:

d1e7d9197b lib/vssh/libssh2.c (Mats Lindestam          2021-09-26 23:20:53 +0200  731)       free(fingerprint_b64);
d1e7d9197b lib/vssh/libssh2.c (Mats Lindestam          2021-09-26 23:20:53 +0200  732) 
d1e7d9197b lib/vssh/libssh2.c (Mats Lindestam          2021-09-26 23:20:53 +0200  733)       failf(data,
ff2f3e8367 lib/vssh/libssh2.c (Daniel Stenberg         2022-04-25 11:41:20 +0200  734)             "Denied establishing ssh session: mismatch sha256 fingerprint. "
ff2f3e8367 lib/vssh/libssh2.c (Daniel Stenberg         2022-04-25 11:41:20 +0200  735)             "Remote %s is not equal to %s", fingerprint_b64, pubkey_sha256);

## Impact

Depends on which memory is the pointer fingerprint_b64 pointing to at the time failf() is called, it may either crash the application or it may print out whatever was in memory at the time leading to information leak in the fail log.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

# Random notes
* It's quite easy to trigger since you only need to make the host fingerprint not match. This can be done by man in the middle for example.
* Crash is somewhat rare as the pointer would need to point to very end of heap, plus the `free()` would also need to to result in buffer that has no `\0` bytes in it for the `mvsnprintf(error, CURL_ERROR_SIZE, fmt, ap);` to overrun. `CURL_ERROR_SIZE` limits the scanning to max 255 bytes.
* Use after free is nearly immediately after `free()`.  As far as I can tell `mvsnprintf(error, CURL_ERROR_SIZE, fmt, ap);`  itself doesn't allocate any heap memory. If so, the only potentially sensitive information is anything that is put to heap as a result of merging free heap blocks (and other management) by the allocator. Some allocators might leak contents of adjacent free blocks if/when block merging occurs. As this behaviour is allocator specific, leaking some potentially sensitive information that is some free block cannot be ruled out. For such leak to occur there must not be any `\0` bytes within the block being merged with the adjacent one.
* Leak is limited to `CURL_ERROR_SIZE - 1` (255)  bytes.  Hence the maximum number of leaked bytes from the adjacent free block (with potentially sensitive data) is: 255 - 45 = 210 bytes (the sha256sum is 44 chars). It likely is less due to specific alignments of block sizes and some bytes being corrupted by next block pointer and block size.

# Mitigating factors
* The leak normally occurs in the context of the application itself. It can in some situations get leaked to different security context: if error is somehow sent to remote site or if libcurl using application is launched as response to some web app or similar). These scenarios are quite rare, but cannot be completely ruled out.
* `CURLOPT_SSH_HOST_PUBLIC_KEY_SHA256` must be used for the issue to trigger *and* either verbose mode `CURLOPT_VERBOSE` need to be enabled  or  `CURLOPT_ERRORBUFFER` used.
* Attacker must somehow be get the signature check not match. However, this could be easy if the attacker can specify the host or the `CURLOPT_SSH_HOST_PUBLIC_KEY_SHA256`, or a bit harder if man in the middle attack is required.

# Thoughts about severity

The severity is not easy to estimate, as different platforms and/or applications using libcurl might exhibit different behaviour.

As a PoC it should be possible to create a specially crafted PHP application that does sftp connection, and has all the necessary options enabled. In this scenario the web app would send any error messages back as response. If the attacker would man in the middle the connection and present a different host key (or could affect which host the app connects to) they could get the fingerprints to mismatch and the bug to trigger. This of course is an artificially crafted example, but I think it proves that this issue could in theory reveal some sensitive information.

Practical leak of sensitive information is rather unlikely however. If there is no practical example of leaking actual sensitive information (other than heap block addresses) I would estimate the severity to no higher than  **Medium**.

Thanks @nyymi for an excellent summary of the situation.

If I would nitpick, then wouldn't the longest possible "leak" of a secret happen if the secret is immediately replaced by something sensitive at the time of the `free()` call (perhaps by another thread doing a malloc and storing secrets in that buffer) and then 255-69 = 186 bytes would be the longest output to leak? The 69 is the number of bytes that prefix the fingerprint in the error message that gets stored and possibly returned.
@bagder Ah indeed, I used the wrong thing when calculating it above. The prefix before the spot where the message would appear is the right thing to subtract from the 255.

@wct: Since this issue is not set **high** nor **critical**, we would like to work on this issue, create a detailed security advisory, create a patch and ideally one or two tests and then **go public in sync with the pending next release** (this might then end up as one out of several issues that go public on the same date). We hope this is okay with you, as otherwise we can certainly discuss and maybe work out an expedited schedule.

(FYI: I'm @bagder not spelled like the animal)

If you prefer a discussion with the curl security team without filing an issue first  - you can email security@curl.se which reaches the team and is a members-only mailing list.
Sorry, my mistake! Didn't meant to sound disrespectful.
Nice. By the way, you will be applying for CVE ID right?

@wct: yes. I usually request a CVE ID for the flaw a few weeks before the pending release date after I have written up the first draft of the security advisory (since then I have a good blurb to paste into the request). If I ask too early, I just get nagged and reminded by the system several more times about publishing it :-)

additional_data.new_title: CVE-2023-28319: UAF in SSH sha256 fingerprint check

activities.message:
Here my first take at an advisory describing this flaw in detail:

---

CVE-2023-28319: UAF in SSH sha256 fingerprint check
====================================================

Project curl Security Advisory, May 17th 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-28319.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

libcurl offers a feature to verify an SSH server's public key using a SHA 256
hash. When this check fails, libcurl would free the memory for the fingerprint
before it returns an error message containing the (now freed) hash.

This flaw risks inserting sensitive heap-based data into the error message
that might be shown to users or otherwise get leaked and revealed.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

This only applies to users of the `CURLOPT_SSH_HOST_PUBLIC_KEY_SHA256` option,
which is **only supported for libcurl built with libssh2** (curl optionally
supports other SSH backends). Either of the options `CURLOPT_VERBOSE` or
`CURLOPT_ERRORBUFFER` also need to be set to trigger the problem.

The damage is somewhat limited by the extremely short time window between the
free and the use of the freed memory.

The largest possible info leak that can happen due to this flaw per trigger
occasion, is limited to `CURL_ERROR_SIZE` - the error message prefix length
(69) = 186 bytes. It will also stop at the first null byte within those 186
bytes.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2023-28319 to this issue.

CWE-416: Use After Free

Severity: Medium

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: curl 7.81.0 to and including 8.0.1
- Not affected versions: curl < 7.81.0 and curl >= 8.1.0

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

THE SOLUTION
------------

The fix for [CVE-2023-28319](pending)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Upgrade curl to version 8.1.0

 B - Apply the patch to your local version

 C - Do not use `CURLOPT_SSH_HOST_PUBLIC_KEY_SHA256`
 
TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on March 21 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on May XX, 2023.

curl 8.1.0 was released on May 17 2023, coordinated with the publication of
this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: Wei Chong Tan
- Patched-by: Daniel Stenberg

Thanks a lot!

>  We contacted distros@openwall on May XX, 2023.

So distros list changed their mind or is that some old copypasta?

I still entertain the chance that they have changed their minds. I have asked them explicitly about it just now and am awaiting their answer. If they still deny us, I will create a new and separate curl notification email list for the similar purpose but for curl notifications only.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
